title: Jeremiah Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 12.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:1, what does Jeremiah ask the LORD about the way of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Why does it prosper?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah questions why the way of the wicked prospers and why those who deal treacherously are happy, as stated in Jeremiah 12:1.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:2, how does God describe the wicked who prosper?
options: They are planted and take root.
questions.correctAnswer: They are planted and take root.
questions.explanation: The wicked are said to be planted, take root, and bring forth fruit according to Jeremiah 12:2.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say God has done to the wicked like sheep, according to Jeremiah 12:3?
options: Pulled them out for the slaughter.
questions.correctAnswer: Pulled them out for the slaughter.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah states that God will pull the wicked out like sheep for the slaughter as mentioned in Jeremiah 12:3.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:4, what happens to the land and its creatures because of the wickedness of the inhabitants?
options: The land mourns and the beasts are consumed.
The land flourishes and animals multiply.
The land is peaceful and full of life.
The land is harvested and blessed.
questions.correctAnswer: The land mourns and the beasts are consumed.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:4 describes the land mourning, herbs withering, and beasts and birds being consumed due to wickedness.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:5, what analogy is used to describe the challenge Jeremiah faces?
options: Running with footmen and contending with horses.
Sailing a boat in a stormy sea.
questions.correctAnswer: Running with footmen and contending with horses.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah compares running with footmen and contending with horses to describe the increasing difficulty he faces in Jeremiah 12:5.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:6 states that even Jeremiah's own family has dealt treacherously with him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:6 says that even his brethren and the house of his father have dealt treacherously with him.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:7, what has Jeremiah forsaken?
questions.correctAnswer: His house and heritage.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah declares that he has forsaken his house and left his heritage as stated in Jeremiah 12:7.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe his heritage in Jeremiah 12:8?
options: As a lion in the forest that crieth out against him.
As a flowing river bringing life.
As a peaceful dove in the sky.
As a fruitful tree in a garden.
questions.correctAnswer: As a lion in the forest that crieth out against him.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah compares his heritage to a lion in the forest crying out against him in Jeremiah 12:8.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:9 describes his heritage as a speckled bird that is supported by other birds.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:9 describes his heritage as a speckled bird that the birds around are against, not supporting.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:10, what have many pastors done to Jeremiah's vineyard?
options: Destroyed it and made it desolate.
Watered it and made it flourish.
questions.correctAnswer: Destroyed it and made it desolate.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:10 states that many pastors have destroyed his vineyard and made the pleasant portion a desolate wilderness.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:11 says the whole land is made desolate, but many people care deeply about it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:11 states the land mourns because no man layeth it to heart, meaning people do not care about it.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 12:12 says the sword of the LORD shall devour from the one end of the land even to the other end of the land; no flesh shall have ______.
questions.correctAnswer: Peace
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:12 states no flesh shall have peace due to the sword of the LORD devouring the land.

questions.question: What will those who sow wheat reap, according to Jeremiah 12:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Thorns
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:13 says they have sown wheat but shall reap thorns.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:14, what will the LORD do to His evil neighbors that touch Israel's inheritance?
options: Pluck them out of their land.
questions.correctAnswer: Pluck them out of their land.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:14 states the LORD will pluck out the evil neighbors from their land.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:15, what will happen after the LORD has plucked out the evil neighbors?
options: He will have compassion and bring them back to their land.
He will send them into exile forever.
He will give their land to others.
questions.correctAnswer: He will have compassion and bring them back to their land.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:15 says the LORD will return, have compassion, and bring them again to their heritage and land.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding why wicked people often seem to prosper. Based on Jeremiah 12:1, what biblical truth would you share about God's righteousness and human circumstances?
options: God is righteous even when the wicked prosper temporarily
Wicked people always suffer immediately for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: God is righteous even when the wicked prosper temporarily
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:1 acknowledges God’s righteousness despite the apparent prosperity of the wicked, teaching believers to trust God’s justice beyond visible circumstances. This is supported by verses 2-3 which show God's perspective on the wicked and the faithful.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 12:3 teach about God's knowledge and testing of the believer's heart during trials?
options: God knows and tests the believer’s heart
God is unaware of our struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God knows and tests the believer’s heart
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that God knows and has tried Jeremiah’s heart, illustrating that God is intimately aware of believers’ faith and uses trials to test and refine their faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer feels weary in peaceful times and fears harder trials ahead. According to Jeremiah 12:5, what advice does God give about enduring greater challenges?
options: If you are tired with small trials, greater trials will be harder
Peaceful times mean no trials will come
Avoid all challenges to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: If you are tired with small trials, greater trials will be harder
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:5 uses the metaphor of running with footmen and horses to illustrate that if one is weary from minor difficulties, greater challenges will be even more demanding, encouraging perseverance and preparation.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 12:6 warn believers about trusting even close relations in times of trial?
options: Even brethren and family may act treacherously
Do not trust anyone outside your family
questions.correctAnswer: Even brethren and family may act treacherously
questions.explanation: Verse 6 reveals that even close relations, like brethren and family, may betray or mislead, teaching believers to be cautious and rely primarily on God’s truth.

questions.question: What spiritual lesson about stewardship and care can be learned from Jeremiah 12:10, where 'many pastors have destroyed my vineyard'?
options: Leaders must faithfully care for God’s people and resources
Neglect by leaders is expected and acceptable
Vineyards are unimportant in spiritual teaching
Pastors should focus only on themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must faithfully care for God’s people and resources
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:10 criticizes leaders who neglect or harm God's people, teaching that spiritual leaders have a responsibility to steward the community faithfully.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the desolation around them. According to Jeremiah 12:11, how should they respond to the mourning land?
options: Be concerned and attentive to spiritual decline
Ignore the desolation as it has no meaning
Rejoice in desolation as a sign of freedom
questions.correctAnswer: Be concerned and attentive to spiritual decline
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:11 expresses sorrow over the desolation and calls for heartfelt concern, encouraging believers to be attentive to spiritual and moral decay.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 12:13, what principle about the consequences of dishonesty and hard work without God’s blessing can be shared?
options: Hard work without God’s favor leads to shame and loss
Reaping thorns means a good harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Hard work without God’s favor leads to shame and loss
questions.explanation: Verse 13 teaches that despite hard work, without God’s blessing, results may be unfruitful and bring shame, emphasizing reliance on God’s favor in all endeavors.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:15 promises that after judgment, God will have compassion and restore His people to their heritage and land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:15 clearly states that after God has judged by removing His people, He will have compassion and bring them back to their land, demonstrating His mercy and restoration.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 12:16 teach about the importance of learning God's ways and swearing by His name?
options: Those who learn and swear by God will be built among His people
Obedience has no effect on community standing
questions.correctAnswer: Those who learn and swear by God will be built among His people
questions.explanation: Verse 16 emphasizes that diligent learning of God’s ways and commitment by swearing His name leads to inclusion and strengthening within God’s community.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 12:17 emphasize the consequence of disobedience for a nation?
options: Disobedience leads to being utterly plucked up and destroyed
Nations are never punished for sin
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to being utterly plucked up and destroyed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:17 warns that refusal to obey God results in severe judgment, illustrating the seriousness of obedience for national survival.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:7-9 uses imagery of a lion and a speckled bird to describe the relationship between God’s heritage and its enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 use vivid imagery of a lion and a speckled bird to depict God’s heritage as endangered and hated by surrounding enemies, underscoring the vulnerability of God’s people.

questions.question: A believer is facing betrayal by those close to them. Based on Jeremiah 12:6, what biblical principle about trust and discernment would you share?
options: Do not always trust even family, test their words
questions.correctAnswer: Do not always trust even family, test their words
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:6 warns that even brethren and family may act treacherously, teaching believers to exercise discernment and not blindly trust others, even close ones.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 12:12 describe the scope of the LORD’s judgment and its effect on peace?
options: The LORD’s judgment will cover the entire land, and no flesh shall have peace
Only a small area will be judged
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD’s judgment will cover the entire land, and no flesh shall have peace
questions.explanation: Verse 12 describes the LORD’s judgment as sweeping across the whole land, leaving no one at peace, emphasizing the comprehensive nature of divine justice.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 12:4 asks, 'How long shall the land mourn, and the herbs of every field wither, for the ______ of them that dwell therein?'
questions.correctAnswer: wickedness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:4 highlights the impact of the wickedness of the inhabitants causing mourning and withering of the land, teaching the consequences of sin on community wellbeing.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 12:14 reveal about God's dealings with neighboring nations who touch His people's inheritance?
options: God will pluck them out of their land
God lets His people share their inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: God will pluck them out of their land
questions.explanation: Verse 14 clearly states that God will remove the evil neighbors who intrude on Israel’s inheritance, demonstrating God’s protection and justice for His people.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 12.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:1, the prophet questions why the wicked prosper and are happy. Which other biblical book similarly grapples with the prosperity of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Job
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:1 questions the prosperity of the wicked, a theme deeply explored in Job where Job wrestles with similar issues of divine justice.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Jeremiah 12:2 to describe the wicked, and what does this suggest about their relationship with God?
options: They are planted and take root, but God is far from their hearts.
They are like scattered sheep, lost and without a shepherd.
They are like a barren tree, with no fruit or life.
They are like a fortress, strongly built and secure.
questions.correctAnswer: They are planted and take root, but God is far from their hearts.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:2 uses the metaphor of being planted and taking root to show that the wicked prosper outwardly, but God is distant from their inner being ('far from their reins').

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:3, what does the phrase 'pull them out like sheep for the slaughter' foreshadow in biblical typology?
options: The judgment of the wicked and the suffering of the righteous.
The exodus of Israel from Egypt.
The sacrifice of Isaac by Abraham.
The anointing of David as king.
questions.correctAnswer: The judgment of the wicked and the suffering of the righteous.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:3's imagery of sheep for slaughter typologically foreshadows divine judgment and suffering, similar to the suffering servant motif.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:4 describes the land mourning because of wickedness. Which historical context best explains this imagery?
options: The Babylonian invasion and exile of Judah.
The conquest of Canaan by Joshua.
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian invasion and exile of Judah.
questions.explanation: The desolation and mourning of the land in Jeremiah 12:4 reflect the historical devastation during the Babylonian exile period.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:5 uses an analogy involving running with footmen and horses. What does this metaphorically represent?
options: Increasing challenges and escalating trials for the people.
The transition from peace to war.
The spiritual growth of the faithful.
The comparison between Israel and other nations.
questions.correctAnswer: Increasing challenges and escalating trials for the people.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:5 uses the metaphor of running with footmen then horses to illustrate increasing difficulties and challenges ahead.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Jeremiah 12:6 where 'brethren' and 'house of thy father' deal treacherously?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:6 contains irony, as those closest to the speaker (brethren and family) are the ones betraying him.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:7-9, what do the metaphors of 'lion in the forest' and 'speckled bird' symbolize in relation to the heritage?
options: The heritage is dangerous and vulnerable, causing distress to the speaker.
The heritage is strong and protective like a lion and a bird.
The heritage is hidden and mysterious like forest creatures.
The heritage is abundant and fruitful.
questions.correctAnswer: The heritage is dangerous and vulnerable, causing distress to the speaker.
questions.explanation: The metaphors in Jeremiah 12:7-9 depict the heritage as threatening and besieged, illustrating the prophet's conflicted feelings.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:10 speaks of 'many pastors' destroying the vineyard. What does this metaphor imply historically and theologically?
options: Leaders (pastors) have failed the people, leading to spiritual desolation.
The people have been fruitful under wise leadership.
The vineyard represents foreign nations' influence.
The destruction is caused by natural disasters.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders (pastors) have failed the people, leading to spiritual desolation.
questions.explanation: The metaphor of pastors destroying the vineyard in Jeremiah 12:10 symbolizes the failure of Israel's leaders to care for God's people, causing devastation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'no flesh shall have peace' in Jeremiah 12:12 within the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It signifies total societal collapse and divine judgment across the land.
It indicates a time of peace and prosperity.
It describes a specific military treaty.
It refers to ritual purification practices.
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies total societal collapse and divine judgment across the land.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:12's phrase reflects the widespread devastation and unrest typical of divine judgment in ancient Near Eastern prophetic literature.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:13, what will happen to those who 'sow wheat'?
options: They shall reap thorns and not profit from their labor.
They will reap a bountiful harvest.
They will prosper and be honored.
They will be blessed with peace.
questions.correctAnswer: They shall reap thorns and not profit from their labor.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:13 warns that despite efforts, the people will face disappointment and divine wrath, reaping thorns instead of wheat.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:14-15 contains a promise of compassion after judgment. How does this reflect the broader biblical theme of restoration?
options: God’s justice is balanced by mercy and restoration to the heritage.
Restoration is only for the Gentiles.
There is no hope after exile.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice is balanced by mercy and restoration to the heritage.
questions.explanation: These verses affirm the biblical theme where judgment is followed by restoration and mercy, consistent with prophetic literature.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:16 outlines a condition for the inclusion of 'evil neighbours' among God's people. What is this condition?
options: They must learn the ways of God and swear by His name.
They must offer sacrifices to Baal.
They must build their own temples.
questions.correctAnswer: They must learn the ways of God and swear by His name.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:16 states that if the neighboring nations learn God's ways and swear by His name, they will be built among His people.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:17 issues a warning concerning disobedience. How does this warning relate to the covenantal theology found elsewhere in the Old Testament?
options: Disobedience leads to being uprooted and destroyed by God.
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to being uprooted and destroyed by God.
questions.explanation: This verse echoes the covenantal principle that disobedience brings judgment, consistent with themes in Deuteronomy and elsewhere.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:11 suggests that the desolation of the land causes the people to be deeply repentant and attentive to their condition.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:11 says the land mourns 'because no man layeth it to heart,' indicating the people are not repentant or attentive.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 12:6 indicates that even close relatives have betrayed the prophet, illustrating a theme of personal and communal treachery.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:6 explicitly mentions that brethren and family have dealt treacherously, highlighting betrayal within the community.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:1, what question does the prophet ask the LORD regarding the wicked?
options: Why does the way of the wicked prosper?
Why does the LORD hide His face?
questions.correctAnswer: Why does the way of the wicked prosper?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:1 explicitly asks why the way of the wicked prospers despite God's righteousness. This question connects with similar biblical themes found in Psalm 73:3-12, Habakkuk 1:13, Ecclesiastes 8:14, and Romans 8:28 where the prosperity of the wicked is questioned in light of God's justice.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:2, how does God describe the wicked in relation to His presence?
options: Near in their mouth, but far from their reins
Far from their mouth, but near in their hearts
questions.correctAnswer: Near in their mouth, but far from their reins
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:2 states that God is near in their mouth, meaning their speech, but far from their reins, indicating their innermost being or heart. This reflects God's omniscience and the hypocrisy of the wicked, similar to Psalms 78:36, Isaiah 29:13, Matthew 15:8, and James 1:26.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 12:3 reveal about God's knowledge of the prophet?
options: God knows and has tried Jeremiah's heart toward Him
God is unaware of Jeremiah's struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God knows and has tried Jeremiah's heart toward Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:3 affirms that God knows Jeremiah intimately and has tested his heart. This highlights God's omniscience and testing of faith, paralleling Job 1:8, Psalm 139:1-2, 1 Chronicles 28:9, and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:4 asks how long the land will mourn because of what reason?
options: Because of the wickedness of those who dwell therein
Because of a drought and famine
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the wickedness of those who dwell therein
questions.explanation: The verse laments the land's mourning due to the wickedness of its inhabitants, showing the connection between sin and creation's suffering. This theme is echoed in Genesis 3:17-18, Romans 8:22, Psalm 107:33-35, and Isaiah 24:5-6.

questions.question: What analogy does Jeremiah 12:5 use to illustrate the prophet’s endurance compared to future challenges?
options: If you wearied running with footmen, how will you contend with horses?
If you have battled with swords, how will you face spears?
If you have walked through deserts, how will you cross rivers?
If you have faced lions, how will you face dragons?
questions.correctAnswer: If you wearied running with footmen, how will you contend with horses?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:5 uses an athletic and military metaphor, challenging endurance and faithfulness amid greater trials. This corresponds with themes in 2 Timothy 4:7, Hebrews 12:1, James 1:12, and Revelation 2:10 about perseverance and trials.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:6, who has dealt treacherously with the prophet?
options: His own brethren and the house of his father
questions.correctAnswer: His own brethren and the house of his father
questions.explanation: This verse reveals betrayal from close kin, emphasizing the prophet’s isolation and the theme of internal treachery, paralleled in Psalm 41:9, John 13:18, Matthew 10:21, and Luke 21:16.

questions.question: What sentiment does Jeremiah express about his heritage in Jeremiah 12:8?
options: He hates it because it cries out against him like a lion
He cherishes it as a blessing
questions.correctAnswer: He hates it because it cries out against him like a lion
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:8 uses the metaphor of a lion to describe his heritage as hostile, causing him to hate it. This reflects the prophet's deep anguish and rejection, similar to Genesis 49:9, Hosea 11:1, Isaiah 5:29, and Revelation 13:2.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 12:10, what have many pastors done to the vineyard?
options: They have destroyed it and trodden it under foot
They have watered and cared for it
They have guarded it from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They have destroyed it and trodden it under foot
questions.explanation: The verse criticizes leaders (pastors) who have neglected and harmed God's people (the vineyard), consistent with Ezekiel 34:2-4, Matthew 23:1-4, Isaiah 5:1-7, and John 10:12-13 concerning pastoral failure.

questions.question: What consequence does Jeremiah 12:12 describe for the land as a result of the LORD's sword?
options: No flesh shall have peace from one end of the land to the other
The land will be fruitful and blessed
The land will be covered in water
questions.correctAnswer: No flesh shall have peace from one end of the land to the other
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 12:12 describes total judgment and devastation, highlighting God's sovereign justice. This imagery is echoed in Isaiah 34:5-10, Joel 3:16, Ezekiel 7:15, and Revelation 6:8 regarding God's judgment.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:13, what will happen to those who sow wheat?
options: They shall reap in due season
questions.correctAnswer: They shall reap thorns
questions.explanation: The verse uses agricultural imagery to show that effort invested by the wicked will yield harmful results, consistent with Hosea 10:12, Galatians 6:7-8, Matthew 7:16-20, and Hebrews 6:7-8.

questions.question: What does the LORD declare He will do to His evil neighbors in Jeremiah 12:14?
options: Pluck them out of their land
questions.correctAnswer: Pluck them out of their land
questions.explanation: This verse pronounces divine judgment on nations touching Israel’s inheritance, reflecting God's protection of His covenant people. Parallels include Leviticus 26:33, Deuteronomy 28:63, Ezekiel 25:3-7, and Amos 9:8.

questions.question: What future hope does Jeremiah 12:15 offer after judgment occurs?
options: God will return and restore each person to their heritage and land
The people will be lost forever
The land will be cursed eternally
questions.correctAnswer: God will return and restore each person to their heritage and land
questions.explanation: This verse promises restoration and compassion after judgment, revealing God's mercy and faithfulness as seen in Ezekiel 36:24-28, Isaiah 11:11-12, Jeremiah 29:14, and Acts 3:21.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 12:16, what condition must the nations meet to be built in the midst of God's people?
options: Diligently learn the ways of God's people and swear by His name
questions.correctAnswer: Diligently learn the ways of God's people and swear by His name
questions.explanation: The verse presents repentance and faith as conditions for inclusion in God's covenant community, consistent with Deuteronomy 6:5, Jeremiah 31:33, Romans 11:17-24, and Galatians 3:28.

questions.question: What consequence does Jeremiah 12:17 warn if the nations refuse to obey God's ways?
options: God will utterly pluck up and destroy that nation
God will cause them to prosper
questions.correctAnswer: God will utterly pluck up and destroy that nation
questions.explanation: This verse underscores God's righteous judgment on persistent disobedience, paralleling Exodus 32:10, Deuteronomy 28:63, 2 Chronicles 36:16, and Hebrews 10:26-27.

questions.question: Jeremiah 12:7 expresses a feeling of abandonment. What has Jeremiah forsaken?
questions.correctAnswer: His house and heritage
questions.explanation: The verse describes Jeremiah's sorrow over losing his familial and national inheritance, a theme of exile and loss consistent with Lamentations 5:18, Psalm 137:1-4, Isaiah 6:11, and Ezekiel 37:12.
